{{Infobox software | name = Gobby | author = [[Armin Burgmeier]] | logo = Gobby-logo.png | screenshot = Gobby-0.4.0-dev-linux.png | caption = Gobby 0.4.0 (stable version) | developer = [https://web.archive.org/web/20060414003816/http://0x539.de/ 0x539 dev group] | latest_release_version = 0.5.0 | latest_release_date = {{Start date and age|2014|08|24}} | programming_language = [[C++]], [[C (programming language)|C]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gobby.0x539.de/trac/#DevelopmentArea |title=What is Gobby? |website=Gobby.0x539.de |date= |accessdate=2016-07-16}}</ref> | operating_system = [[Unix]], [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] | genre = [[Text editor]] | license = [[GNU General Public License Version 2|GNU GPLv2]]+<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gobby.0x539.de/trac/browser/COPYING |title=What is Gobby? |website=Gobby.0x539.de |date= |accessdate=2016-07-16}}</ref> | website = {{URL|gobby.0x539.de}} }} '''Gobby''' is a [[free software]] [[collaborative real-time editor]] available on Windows and [[Unix-like]] platforms.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.linux.com/news/collaborative-text-editing-gobby|title=Collaborative text editing with Gobby}}</ref> (It runs on [[Mac OS X]] using Apple's [[X11.app]].) It was initially released in June 2005 by the 0x539 dev group.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gobby.0x539.de/trac/wiki/News#a2005-06-07:Gobby0.1.1released |title=What is Gobby? |website=Gobby.0x539.de |date= |accessdate=2016-07-16}}</ref> (The [[hexadecimal]] value 0x539 is equal to [[Leet|1337]] in [[decimal]].) Gobby uses [[GTK+]] for its [[GUI widget]]s.
It features a client-server architecture which supports multiple documents in one session, document synchronisation on request, password protection and an [[IRC]]-like chat for communication [[out of band]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.linux.com/news/group-text-editing-gobby|title=Group text editing with Gobby}}</ref> Users can choose a colour to highlight the text they have written in a document. Gobby is fully [[Unicode]]-aware, provides [[syntax highlighting]] for most programming languages and has basic [[Zeroconf]] support.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gobby.0x539.de/trac/wiki/News#a2005-07-30:Releaseday-gobby-0.2.0obby-0.2.0net6-1.1.0 |title=What is Gobby? |website=Gobby.0x539.de |date= |accessdate=2016-07-16}}</ref>
A dedicated server called Sobby is also provided, together with a script which could format saved sessions for the web (e.g. to provide logs of meetings with a collaboratively prepared transcript). The collaborative editing protocol is named Obby, and there are other implementations that use this protocol (e.g. Rudel,<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.emacswiki.org/emacs/Rudel |title=Rudel |website=EmacsWiki.org |date=2014-10-23 |accessdate=2016-07-16}}</ref> a plugin for [[GNU Emacs]]). Gobby 0.5 replaces Sobby with a new server called infinoted.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gobby.0x539.de/trac/wiki/Infinote/Infinoted |title=What is Gobby? |website=Gobby.0x539.de |date= |accessdate=2016-07-16}}</ref>
Version 0.4.0 featured [[GnuTLS|fully encrypted]] connections and further usability enhancements.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gobby.0x539.de/trac/wiki/News#a2006-04-11:Firstreleasecandidateofthe0.4.xseries |title=What is Gobby? |website=Gobby.0x539.de |date= |accessdate=2016-07-16}}</ref>
Versions numbered 0.4.9x are preview releases for version 0.5.0. The most noticeable improvement is [[undo]] support,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gobby.0x539.de/trac/wiki#a2008-10-18:Gobby0.4.90 |title=What is Gobby?|website=Gobby.0x539.de |date= |accessdate=2016-07-16}}</ref> using the [[Operational transformation#OT control (integration) algorithms|adOPTed]] algorithm for concurrency control.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gobby.0x539.de/trac/wiki/Infinote/Protocol#ConcurrencyControl |title=What is Gobby?|website=Gobby.0x539.de |date= |accessdate=2016-07-16}}</ref>
==See also== {{Wiktionary|gobby}} {{Portal|Free Software}} *[[Collaborative real-time editor]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{Official website|gobby.0x539.de/trac/}} * [http://techmonks.net/working-together-on-text-and-source-code-with-gobby-and-infinoted Working together on text and source code with Gobby and infinoted] * [https://debaday.debian.net/2007/04/04/gobby-a-collaborative-text-editor/ Gobby: A Collaborative Text Editor]

revision.text:
'''Homogeneous charge compression ignition''' ('''HCCI''') is a form of [[internal combustion engine|internal combustion]] in which well-mixed [[fuel]] and [[oxidizer]] (typically air) are compressed to the point of auto-ignition. As in other forms of [[combustion]], this [[exothermic reaction]] releases energy that can be transformed in an engine into [[Work (thermodynamics)|work]] and heat. HCCI combines characteristics of conventional [[gasoline engine]] and [[diesel engine]]s. Gasoline engines combine ''homogeneous charge'' (HC) with ''[[spark ignition]]'' (SI), abbreviated as HCSI. Diesel engines combine ''[[stratified charge]]'' (SC) with ''[[compression ignition]]'' (CI), abbreviated as SCCI. As in HCSI, HCCI injects fuel during the intake stroke. However, rather than using an electric discharge (spark) to ignite a portion of the mixture, HCCI raises density and temperature by compression until the entire mixture reacts spontaneously. Stratified charge compression ignition also relies on temperature and density increase resulting from compression. However, it injects fuel later, during the compression stroke. Combustion occurs at the boundary of the fuel and air, producing higher emissions, but allowing a [[Lean burn|leaner]] and higher compression burn, producing greater efficiency. [[control theory|Controlling]] HCCI requires microprocessor control and physical understanding of the ignition process. HCCI designs achieve gasoline engine-like emissions with diesel engine-like efficiency. HCCI engines achieve extremely low levels of oxides of nitrogen emissions ({{chem|NO|x}}) without a [[catalytic converter]]. Hydrocarbons (unburnt fuels and oils) and carbon monoxide emissions still require treatment to meet [[automobile emissions control]] regulations. Recent research has shown that the hybrid fuels combining different reactivities (such as gasoline and diesel) can help in controlling HCCI ignition and burn rates. RCCI, or reactivity controlled compression ignition, has been demonstrated to provide highly efficient, low emissions operation over wide load and speed ranges.{{cite web|url=http://www.engr.wisc.edu/news/headlines/2009/Aug03.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100225044550/http://www.engr.wisc.edu/news/headlines/2009/Aug03.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2010-02-25 |title=College of Engineering @ The University of Wisconsin-Madison, initiatives in energy, health, nanotechnology, security, and information technology |publisher=Engr.wisc.edu |accessdate=2014-03-31 }}.This HCCI system can be highly efficient with the help of free piston engine == History == HCCI engines have a long history, even though HCCI has not been as widely implemented as spark ignition or diesel injection. It is essentially an [[Otto cycle|Otto combustion cycle]]. HCCI was popular before electronic [[ignition system|spark ignition]] was used. One example is the [[Hot bulb engine|hot-bulb engine]] which used a hot vaporization chamber to help mix fuel with air. The extra heat combined with compression induced the conditions for combustion. Another example is the [[Carbureted compression ignition model engine|"diesel" model aircraft engine]]. == Operation == === Methods === A mixture of fuel and air ignites when the concentration and temperature of reactants is sufficiently high. The concentration and/or temperature can be increased in several different ways: * Increasing compression ratio * Pre-heating of induction gases * Forced induction * Retained or re-inducted exhaust gases Once ignited, combustion occurs very quickly. When auto-ignition occurs too early or with too much chemical energy, combustion is too fast and high in-cylinder pressures can destroy an engine. For this reason, HCCI is typically operated at lean overall fuel mixtures. === Advantages === * Since HCCI engines are fuel-lean, they can operate at diesel-like compression ratios (>15), thus achieving 30% higher efficiencies than conventional SI gasoline engines. {{cite book | first1 = Fuquan | last1 = Zhao | first2 = Thomas W. | last2 = Asmus | first3 = Dennis N. | last3 = Assanis | first4 = John E. | last4 = Dec | first5 = James A. | last5 = Eng | first6 = Paul M. | last6 = Najt | title = Homogeneous Charge Compression Ignition (HCCI) Engines: Key Research and Development Issues | publisher = [[Society of Automotive Engineers]] | location = Warrendale, PA, USA | year = 2003 | pages = 11–12 | isbn = 0-7680-1123-X }} * Homogeneous mixing of fuel and air leads to cleaner combustion and lower emissions. Because peak temperatures are significantly lower than in typical SI engines, [[NOx|{{chem|NO|NOx}}]] levels are almost negligible. Additionally, the technique does not produce [[soot]]. {{cite book | first1 = Jürgen | last1 = Warnatz | first2 = Ulrich | last2 = Maas | first3 = Robert W. | last3 = Dibble | title = Combustion: Physical and Chemical Fundamentals, Modeling and Simulation, Experiments, Pollutant Formation | publisher = [[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]] | location = Berlin, Germany | edition = 4th | year = 2006 | pages = 175–176 | isbn = 3-540-25992-9 }} * HCCI engines can operate on gasoline, diesel fuel, and most alternative fuels. {{cite journal | first1 = John E. | last1 = Dec | first2 = Kathy | last2 = Epping | first3 = Salvador M. | last3 = Aceves | first4 = Richard L. | last4 = Bechtold | title = The Potential of HCCI Combustion for High Efficiency and Low Emissions | journal = Society of Automotive Engineers | year = 2002 | id = 2002-01-1923 }} * HCCI avoids throttle losses, which further improves efficiency. {{cite book | last = Baumgarten | first = Carsten | title = Mixture Formation in Internal Combustion Engines: Mixture Formation in Internal Combustion Engines | publisher = Birkhäuser | year = 2006 | pages = 263–264 | isbn = 3-540-30835-0 }} === Disadvantages === * Achieving cold start capability. * High heat release and pressure rise rates contribute to engine wear. * Autoignition is difficult to control, unlike the ignition event in SI and [[diesel engine]]s, which are controlled by spark plugs and in-cylinder fuel injectors, respectively. {{cite journal | first1 = Rolf | last1 = Johansson | first2 = Daniel | last2 = Blom | first3 = Maria | last3 = Karlsson | first4 = Kent | last4 = Ekholm | first5 = Per | last5 = Tunestal | title = HCCI Engine Modeling and Control using Conservation Principles | journal = Society of Automotive Engineers | year = 2008 | id = 2008-01-0789 }} * HCCI engines have a small power range, constrained at low loads by lean flammability limits and high loads by in-cylinder pressure restrictions. {{cite journal | last = Stanglmaier | first = Rudolf | title = Homogeneous Charge Compression Ignition (Hcci): Benefits, Compromises, and Future Engine Applications | journal = Society of Automotive Engineers | year = 1999 | id = 1999-01-3682 }} * [[Carbon monoxide]] (CO) and [[hydrocarbon]] (HC) pre-catalyst emissions are higher than a typical spark ignition engine, caused by incomplete oxidation (due to the rapid combustion event and low in-cylinder temperatures) and trapped crevice gases, respectively. {{cite journal | first1 = Salvador M. | last1 = Aceves | first2 = Daniel L. | last2 = Flowers | first3 = Francisco | last3 = Espinosa-Loza | first4 = Joel | last4 = Martinez-Frias | first5 = John E. | last5 = Dec | first6 = Magnus | last6 = Sjöberg | first7 = Robert W. | last7 = Dibble | first8 = Randy P. | last8 = Hessel | title = Spatial Analysis of Emissions Sources for Hcci Combustion At Low Loads Using a Multi-Zone Model | journal = Society of Automotive Engineers | year = 2004 | id = 2004-01-1910 }} === Control === HCCI is more difficult to control than other combustion engines, such as SI and diesel. In a typical [[gasoline engine]], a spark is used to ignite the pre-mixed fuel and air. In [[Diesel engines]], combustion begins when the fuel is injected into pre-compressed air. In both cases, combustion timing is explicitly controlled. In an HCCI engine, however, the homogeneous mixture of fuel and air is compressed and combustion begins whenever sufficient pressure and temperature are reached. This means that no well-defined combustion initiator provides direct control. Engines must be designed so that ignition conditions occur at the desired timing. To achieve dynamic operation, the [[control system]] must manage the conditions that induce combustion. Options include the compression ratio, inducted gas temperature, inducted gas pressure, fuel-air ratio, or quantity of retained or re-inducted exhaust. Several control approaches are discussed below. ==== Compression ratio ==== Two compression ratios are significant. The ''[[geometric compression ratio]]'' can be changed with a movable plunger at the top of the [[cylinder head]]. This system is used in diesel [[Model engine|model aircraft engines]]. The ''[[effective compression ratio]]'' can be reduced from the geometric ratio by closing the intake valve either very late or very early with [[variable valve actuation]] ([[variable valve timing]] that enables the [[Miller cycle]]). Both approaches require energy to achieve fast response. Additionally, implementation is expensive, but is effective. {{cite journal | first1 = Goran | last1 = Haraldsson | first2 = Jari | last2 = Hyvonen | first3 = Per | last3 = Tunestal | first4 = Bengt | last4 = Johansson | title = Hcci Combustion Phasing in a Multi-Cylinder Engine Using Variable Compression Ratio | journal = Society of Automotive Engineers | year = 2002 | id = 2002-01-2858 }} The effect of compression ratio on HCCI combustion has also been studied extensively. {{cite journal | last = Pitz | first = William J. | author2 = SM Aceves | author3 = JR Smith | author4 = CK Westbrook | title = Compression ratio effect on methane HCCI combustion | journal = Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power-Transactions of the ASME | year = 1999 | volume = 212 | issue = 3 | pages = 569–574 }} ==== Induction temperature ==== HCCI's autoignition event is highly sensitive to temperature. The simplest temperature control method uses resistance heaters to vary the inlet temperature, but this approach is too slow to change on a cycle-to-cycle frequency. {{cite journal | last = Flowers | first = Daniel L. | author2 = S. M. Aceves | author3 = J. Martinez-Frias | author4 = J. R. Smith | author5 = M. Y. Au | author6 = J. W. Girard | author7 = R. W. Dibble | title = Operation of a four-cylinder 1.9 l propane-fueled homogeneous charge compression ignition engine: Basic operating characteristics and cylinder-to-cylinder effects | journal = Society of Automotive Engineers | year = 2001 | id = 2001-01-1895 }} Another technique is ''fast thermal management'' (FTM). It is accomplished by varying the intake charge temperature by mixing hot and cold air streams. It is fast enough to allow cycle-to-cycle control. {{cite journal | last = Haraldsson | first = Goran | author2 = Jari Hyvonen | author3 = Per Tunestal | author4 = Bengt Johansson | title = HCCI Closed-Loop Combustion Control Using Fast Thermal Management | journal = Society of Automotive Engineers | year = 2004 | id = 2004-01-0943 }} It is also expensive to implement and has limited bandwidth associated with actuator energy. ==== Exhaust gas percentage ==== Exhaust gas is very hot if retained or re-inducted from the previous combustion cycle or cool if recirculated through the intake as in conventional [[Exhaust gas recirculation|EGR]] systems. The exhaust has dual effects on HCCI combustion. It dilutes the fresh charge, delaying ignition and reducing the chemical energy and engine output. Hot combustion products conversely increase gas temperature in the cylinder and advance ignition. Control of combustion timing HCCI engines using EGR has been shown experimentally. {{cite journal | first1 = Michael | last1 = Au | first2 = J. W. | last2 = Girard | first3 = R. | last3 = Dibble | first4 = D. F. S. M. | last4 = Aceves | first5 = J. | last5 = Martinez-Frias | first6 = R. | last6 = Smith | first7 = C. | last7 = Seibel | first8 = U. | last8 = Maas | title = 1.9-liter four-cylinder HCCI engine operation with exhaust gas recirculation | journal = Society of Automotive Engineers | year = 2001 | id = 2001-01-1894 }} ==== Valve actuation ==== ''[[Variable valve actuation]]'' (VVA) extends the HCCI operating region by giving finer control over the temperature-pressure-time envelope within the combustion chamber. VVA can achieve this via either: * Controlling the effective compression ratio: VVA on intake can control the point at which the intake valve closes. Retarding past bottom dead center (BDC), changes the compression ratio, altering the in-cylinder pressure-time envelope. * Controlling the amount of hot exhaust gas retained in the combustion chamber: VVA can control the amount of hot EGR within the combustion chamber, either by valve re-opening or changes in valve overlap. Balancing the percentage of cooled external EGR with the hot internal EGR generated by a VVA system, makes it possible to control the in-cylinder temperature. While electro-hydraulic and camless VVA systems offer control over the valve event, the componentry for such systems is currently complicated and expensive. Mechanical variable lift and duration systems, however, although more complex than a standard valvetrain, are cheaper and less complicated. It is relatively simple to configure such systems to achieve the necessary control over the valve lift curve. ==== Fuel mixture ==== Another means to extend the operating range is to control the onset of ignition and the heat release rate[http://www.cmclinnovations.com/userstories/userstory1.html Controlling Heat Release Using Advanced Fuels] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110405164105/http://www.cmclinnovations.com/userstories/userstory1.html |date=2011-04-05 }} {{cite journal | last = Smallbone | first = Andrew | author2 = Amit Bhave | author3 = Neal M. Morgan | author4 =Markus Kraft | author5 = Roger Cracknell | author6 = Gautam Kalghatgi | title = Simulating combustion of practical fuels and blends for modern engine applications using detailed chemical kinetics | journal = Society of Automotive Engineers | year = 2010 | id = 2010-01-0572 }} by manipulating the fuel itself. This is usually carried out by blending multiple fuels "on the fly" for the same engine. {{cite journal | last = Sebastian | first = Mosbach | author2 = Ali M. Aldawood | author3 = Markus Kraft | title = Real-Time Evaluation of a Detailed Chemistry HCCI Engine Model Using a Tabulation Technique | journal = Combustion Science and Technology | year = 2008 | volume = 180 | issue = 7 | pages = 1263–1277 | doi=10.1080/00102200802049414 }} Examples include blending of commercial gasoline and diesel fuels,[http://www.cmclinnovations.com/userstories/userstory1.html Blending practical fuels] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110405164105/http://www.cmclinnovations.com/userstories/userstory1.html |date=2011-04-05 }} adopting natural gas [http://www.cmclinnovations.com/userstories/userstory10.html Natural gas combustion] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110405164110/http://www.cmclinnovations.com/userstories/userstory10.html |date=2011-04-05 }} or ethanol ".[http://www.cmclinnovations.com/userstories/userstory3.html ethanol/gasoline blending] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110405164115/http://www.cmclinnovations.com/userstories/userstory3.html |date=2011-04-05 }} This can be achieved in a number of ways: * Upstream blending: Fuels are mixed in the liquid phase, one with low ignition resistance (such as diesel) and a second with greater resistance (gasoline). Ignition timing varies with the ratio of these fuels. * In-chamber blending: One fuel can be injected in the intake duct (port injection) and the other directly into the cylinder. ==== Direct Injection: PCCI or PPCI Combustion ==== Compression Ignition Direct Injection (CIDI) combustion is a well-established means of controlling ignition timing and heat release rate and is adopted in [[diesel engine]] combustion. [[Partially premixed combustion|Partially Pre-mixed Charge Compression Ignition]] (PPCI) also known as Premixed Charge Compression Ignition (PCCI) is a compromise offering the control of CIDI combustion with the reduced exhaust gas emissions of HCCI, specifically lower [[soot]]. {{cite journal | last = Kalghatgi | first = G | author2 = Hildingsson, L. | author3 = Johansson, B. | title = Low NOx and low smoke operation of a diesel engine using gasoline-like fuels | journal = ASME ICES2009 | year = 2009 }} The heat release rate is controlled by preparing the combustible mixture in such a way that combustion occurs over a longer time duration making it less prone to [[engine knocking|knocking]]. This is done by timing the injection event such that a range of air/fuel ratios spread across the combustion cylinder when ignition begins. Ignition occurs in different regions of the combustion chamber at different times - slowing the heat release rate. This mixture is designed to minimize the number of fuel-rich pockets, reducing soot formation.{{cite web |url=http://www.cmclinnovations.com/userstories/userstory2.html |title=Partially-Premixed Compression Ignition (PPCI) and Low-Temperature Combustion (LTC) modes |department= |website=Cmcl |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120309041652/http://www.cmclinnovations.com/userstories/userstory2.html |archive-date=2012-03-09 |dead-url=yes |access-date=2016-04-06 |quote=One promising approach is that of Partially-Premixed Compression Ignition (PPCI) or Low Temperature Combustion (LTC) mode. Using this approach, smoke can be reduced in compression ignition engines by promoting the mixing of fuel and air prior to combustion. NOx levels can be reduced by reducing combustion temperatures by burning leaner, pre-mixed or using EGR, exhaust gas recirculation.}} The adoption of high EGR and diesel fuels with a greater resistance to ignition (more "gasoline like") enable longer mixing times before ignition and thus fewer rich pockets that produce soot and {{chem|NO|x}} === Peak pressure and heat release rate === In a typical ICE, combustion occurs via a flame. Hence at any point in time, only a fraction of the total fuel is burning. This results in low peak pressures and low energy release rates. In HCCI however, the entire fuel/air mixture ignites and burns over a much smaller time interval, resulting in high peak pressures and high energy release rates. To withstand the higher pressures, the engine has to be structurally stronger. Several strategies have been proposed to lower the rate of combustion and peak pressure. Mixing fuels, with different autoignition properties, can lower the combustion speed. {{cite journal | last = Mack | first = J. Hunter | author2 = Daniel L. Flowers | author3 = Bruce A. Buchholz | author4 = Robert W. Dibble | title = Investigation of HCCI combustion of diethyl ether and ethanol mixtures using carbon 14 tracing and numerical simulations | journal = Proceedings of the Combustion Institute | year = 2005 | volume = 30 | pages = 2693–2700 | doi=10.1016/j.proci.2004.08.136}} However, this requires significant infrastructure to implement. Another approach uses dilution (i.e. with exhaust gases) to reduce the pressure and combustion rates (and output). {{cite journal | last = Choi | first = GH | author2 = SB Han | author3 = RW Dibble | title = Experimental study on homogeneous charge compression ignition engine operation with exhaust gas recirculation | journal = International Journal of Automotive Technology | year = 2004 | volume = 5 | number = 3 | pages = 195–200 }} In the '''divided combustion chamber''' approach[http://www.pattakon.com/pattakonPatBam.htm], there are two cooperating combustion chambers: a small auxiliary and a big main.
A high compression ratio is used in the auxiliary combustion chamber.
A moderate compression ratio is used in the main combustion chamber wherein a homogeneous air-fuel mixture is compressed / heated near, yet below, the auto-ignition threshold.
The high compression ratio in the auxiliary combustion chamber causes the auto-ignition of the homogeneous lean air-fuel mixture therein (no spark plug required); the burnt gas bursts - through some "transfer ports", just before the TDC - into the main combustion chamber triggering its auto-ignition.
The engine needs not be structurally stronger. === Power === In ICEs, power can be increased by introducing more fuel into the combustion chamber. These engines can withstand a boost in power because the heat release rate in these engines is slow. However, in HCCI engines increasing the fuel/air ratio results in higher peak pressures and heat release rates. In addition, many viable HCCI control strategies require thermal preheating of the fuel, which reduces the density and hence the mass of the air/fuel charge in the combustion chamber, reducing power. These factors make increasing the power in HCCI engines challenging. One technique is to use fuels with different [[autoignition]] properties. This lowers the heat release rate and peak pressures and makes it possible to increase the equivalence ratio. Another way is to thermally stratify the charge so that different points in the compressed charge have different temperatures and burn at different times, lowering the heat release rate and making it possible to increase power. {{cite journal | last = Sjoberg | first = Magnus | author2 = John E. Dec | author3 = Nicholas P. Cernansky | title = Potential of Thermal Stratification and Combustion Retard for Reducing Pressure-Rise Rates in Hcci Engines, Based on Multi-Zone Modelling and Experiments | journal = Society of Automotive Engineers | year = 2005 | id = 2005-01-0113 }} A third way is to run the engine in HCCI mode only at part load conditions and run it as a diesel or SI engine at higher load conditions. {{cite journal | last = Yang | first = Jialin | author2 = Todd Culp | author3 = Thomas Kenney | title = Development of a Gasoline Engine System Using Hcci Technology - The Concept and the Test Results | journal = Society of Automotive Engineers | year = 2002 | id = 2002-01-2832 }} === Emissions === Because HCCI operates on lean mixtures, the peak temperature is much lower than that encountered in SI and diesel engines. This low peak temperature reduces the formation of {{chem|NO|x}}, but it also leads to incomplete burning of fuel, especially near combustion chamber walls. This produces relatively high carbon monoxide and hydrocarbon emissions. An oxidizing catalyst can remove the regulated species, because the exhaust is still oxygen-rich. === Difference from knock === Engine knock or pinging occurs when some of the unburnt gases ahead of the flame in an SI engine spontaneously ignite. This gas is compressed as the flame propagates and the pressure in the combustion chamber rises. The high pressure and corresponding high temperature of unburnt reactants can cause them to spontaneously ignite. This causes a shock wave to traverse from the end gas region and an expansion wave to traverse into the end gas region. The two waves reflect off the boundaries of the combustion chamber and interact to produce high amplitude [[standing waves]], thus forming a primitive thermoacoustic device where the resonance is amplified by the increased heat release during the wave travel similar to a [[Rijke tube]]. A similar ignition process occurs in HCCI. However, rather than part of the reactant mixture igniting by compression ahead of a flame front, ignition in HCCI engines occurs due to piston compression more or less simultaneously in the bulk of the compressed charge. Little or no pressure differences occur between the different regions of the gas, eliminating any shock wave and knocking, but the rapid pressure rise is still present and desirable from the point of seeking maximum efficiency from near-ideal isochoric heat addition. === Simulation of HCCI Engines === Computational models for simulating combustion and heat release rates of HCCI engines require detailed chemistry models.{{cite web |url=https://www-pls.llnl.gov/?url=science_and_technology-chemistry-combustion |title=Combustion Chemistry |publisher=Pls.llnl.gov |accessdate=2014-03-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140817184821/https://www-pls.llnl.gov/?url=science_and_technology-chemistry-combustion |archivedate=2014-08-17 |df= }}
http://www.cmclinnovations.com/?page_id=67 This is largely because ignition is more sensitive to chemical kinetics than to turbulence/spray or spark processes as are typical in SI and diesel engines. Computational models have demonstrated the importance of accounting for the fact that the in-cylinder mixture is actually in-homogeneous, particularly in terms of temperature. This in-homogeneity is driven by turbulent mixing and heat transfer from the combustion chamber walls. The amount of temperature stratification dictates the rate of heat release and thus tendency to knock. {{cite journal | last = Maigaard | first = P | author2 = Fabian Mauss | author3 = Markus Kraft | title = Homogeneous Charge Compression Ignition Engine: A Simulation Study on the Effects of Inhomogeneities | journal = Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power | year = 2003 | volume = 125 | pages = 466–471 | doi=10.1115/1.1563240}} This limits the usefulness of considering the in-cylinder mixture as a single zone, resulting in the integration of 3D [[computational fluid dynamics]] codes such as [[Los Alamos National Laboratory|Los Alamos National Laboratory's]] [[KIVA (software)|KIVA]] [[Computational fluid dynamics|CFD]] code and faster solving probability density function modelling codes.[http://www.cmclinnovations.com/products/srmsuite/srmsuite-advanced.html srm engine suite software] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110409215258/http://www.cmclinnovations.com/products/srmsuite/srmsuite-advanced.html |date=2011-04-09 }}[http://www1.eere.energy.gov/vehiclesandfuels/pdfs/success/modeling_combustion_processes.pdf Modeling combustion processes] == Prototypes == As of 2017, no HCCI engines were produced at commercial scale. However, several car manufacturers had functioning HCCI prototypes. * The 1994 [[Honda EXP-2]] motorcycle used "ARC-combustion". This had a two stroke engine uses an exhaust valve to mimic a HCCI mode. Honda sold a CRM 250 AR. * In 2007-2009, [[General Motors]] demonstrated HCCI with a modified 2.2 L [[GM Ecotec engine|Ecotec engine]] installed in [[Opel Vectra]] and [[Saturn Aura]].{{cite web|author= Sam Abuelsamid RSS feed |url=http://www.autobloggreen.com/2007/08/26/abg-tech-analysis-and-driving-impression-gms-hcci-engine |title=ABG Tech analysis and driving impression: GM's HCCI Engine |publisher=Autobloggreen.com |accessdate=2014-03-31}}
{{cite web|author= Sam Abuelsamid RSS feed |url=http://green.autoblog.com/2009/05/25/gms-hcci-engines-now-run-from-idle-to-60-mph |title=GM's HCCI engines now run from idle to 60 mph! |publisher=Green.autoblog.com |accessdate=2014-03-31}}
{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2011/05/gmhcci-20110503.html |title=GM exploring different valving strategies to extend HCCI operation for high loads; benefits of a Positive Valve Overlap approach |publisher=Green Car Congress |date=2011-05-03 |accessdate=2014-03-31}} The engine operates in HCCI mode at speeds below {{convert|60|mph|km/h}} or when cruising, switching to conventional SI when the throttle is opened and produces fuel economy of {{convert|43|mpgimp}} and carbon dioxide emissions of about 150 grams per kilometre, improving on the {{convert|37|mpgimp}} and 180 g/km of the conventional [[GM Ecotec engine#DI|2.2 L direct injection]] version.{{cite web|author=Michael Scarlett |url=http://www.autoexpress.co.uk/carreviews/firstdrives/222168/vauxhall_vectra_22_hcci.html |title=Vauxhall Vectra 2.2 HCCI |publisher=Auto Express |date=2008-05-21 |accessdate=2014-03-31}} GM is also researching smaller [[GM Family 0 engine#HCCI|Family 0]] engines for HCCI applications. GM has used [[KIVA (software)|KIVA]] in the development of direct-injection, stratified charge gasoline engines as well as the fast burn, homogeneous-charge gasoline engine. * [[Mercedes-Benz]] developed a prototype engine called [[DiesOtto]], with controlled auto ignition. It was displayed in its [[Mercedes-Benz F700|F 700]] concept car at the 2007 Frankfurt Auto Show.{{cite news|url=http://www.edmunds.com/insideline/do/News/articleId=122567 |title=2007 Frankfurt Auto Show: Mercedes-Benz F 700 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012160822/http://www.edmunds.com/insideline/do/News/articleId%3D122567 |work=Edmunds |date=2007-09-11 |archivedate=2007-10-12 |deadurl=yes |df= }} * [[Volkswagen]] are developing two types of engine for HCCI operation. The first, called Combined Combustion System or CCS, is based on the VW Group 2.0-litre diesel engine, but uses homogeneous intake charge. It requires [[synthetic fuel]] to achieve maximum benefit. The second is called Gasoline Compression Ignition or GCI; it uses HCCI when cruising and spark ignition when accelerating. Both engines have been demonstrated in [[Volkswagen Touran|Touran]] prototypes.{{cite web|author=Christian Steinert, The German Car Blog |url=http://www.germancarblog.com/2007/06/vw-inside-secret-laboratory.html |title=VW: Inside the secret laboratory |publisher=The German Car Blog |date=2007-06-27 |accessdate=2014-03-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130518205856/http://www.germancarblog.com/2007/06/vw-inside-secret-laboratory.html |archivedate=2013-05-18}} * In November 2011 [[Hyundai Motor Company|Hyundai]] announced the development of [[Partially premixed combustion|GDCI]] (Gasoline Direct Injection Compression Ignition) engine in association with [[Delphi Automotive]].{{Cite web|title = We Have Ignition: Hyundai's Experimental Gas Engine Runs Without Spark Plugs - Tech Dept.|url = http://www.caranddriver.com/features/hyundais-experimental-gas-engine-runs-without-spark-plugs-feature|website = www.caranddriver.com|accessdate = 2015-11-09}} The engine completely eliminated the ignition plugs, and instead utilizes both supercharger and turbocharger to maintain the pressure within the cylinder. The engine is scheduled for commercial production in near future.{{Cite web|title = (Korean) 현대자동차가 세계시장에 내놓을 비장의 무기|url = http://pub.chosun.com/client/news/viw.asp?cate=C06&mcate=M1038&nNewsNumb=20150417206&nidx=17207|website = chosun.com|accessdate = 2015-11-09|date = 2015-04-23|publisher = [[Chosun Ilbo]]}} * In October 2005, the [[Wall Street Journal]] reported that [[Honda]] was developing an HCCI engine as part of an effort to produce a next generation hybrid car.[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB113012596439377320 Wall Street Journal: Honda's Experimental Hybrid May Help in Race With Toyota] * Oxy-Gen Combustion, a UK-based Clean Technology company, produced a full-load HCCI concept engine with the aid of Michelin and Shell.{{cite web|url=http://www.oxy-gencombustion.com |title=Oxy-Gen Combustion |publisher=Oxy-Gen Combustion |accessdate=2014-03-31}} * Mazda's [[SkyActiv]]-G Generation 2 has a compression ratio of 18:1 to allow the use of HCCI combustion.{{cite web|url=http://phys.org/news/2014-03-cleaner-electric-mazda-gasoline-fuel.html |title=Cleaner than electric? Mazda talks up gasoline engine fuel economy ambitions for SkyActiv 2 |publisher=Phys.org |accessdate=2014-03-31}} An engine model called ''SKYACTIV-X'' has been announced by Mazda in August 2017 as a ''major breakthrough in engine technology''.[https://ca.finance.yahoo.com/news/mazda-touts-gasoline-engine-drive-longer-term-strategy-044456888--finance.html Mazda announces breakthrough in long-coveted engine technology], [[Yahoo!]] finance * Mazda is undertaking research with HCCI with [[Wankel engine]]s.{{cite news |url=http://www.carsguide.com.au/car-news/mazda-skyactiv-r-rotary-could-use-compression-ignition-36576 |title=Mazda SkyActiv-R rotary could use compression ignition- Car News |first=Malcolm |last=Flynn |work=CarsGuide |location=Australia |date=2015-11-09 |access-date=2016-08-08}} == Other applications == To date, few prototype engines run in HCCI mode, but HCCI research has resulted in advancements in fuel and engine development. Examples include: * PCCI/PPCI combustion—A hybrid of HCCI and conventional diesel combustion offering more control over ignition and heat release rates with lower soot and {{chem|NO|x}} emissions. * Advancements in fuel modelling—HCCI combustion is driven mainly by chemical kinetics rather than turbulent mixing or injection, reducing the complexity of simulating the chemistry, which results in fuel oxidation and emissions formation. This has led to increasing interest and development of chemical kinetics that describe hydrocarbon oxidation. * Fuel blending applications—Due to the advancements in fuel modelling, it is now possible to carry out detailed simulations of hydrocarbon fuel oxidation, enabling simulations of practical fuels such as gasoline/diesel and [[ethanol]]. Engineers can now blend fuels virtually and determine how they will perform in an engine context. ==See also== * [[DiesOtto|Mercedes DiesOtto engine]] * [[Internal combustion engine]] * [[Gasoline engine]] * [[Diesel engine]] * [[Free-piston engine]] * [[Variable valve timing]] * [[Helical camshaft]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050305172615/http://www.vok.lth.se/~ce/Publ/publ_en.htm Research, publications at Lund University, SE] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050406082448/http://www.tfd.chalmers.se/~ogink/ Research at Chalmers University of Technology, SE] * [http://ddl.stanford.edu/hcci/ Research at Stanford University, USA] * [http://www.erc.wisc.edu/experimental/experimental_index.htm Research, publications at University of Wisconsin, Madison, USA] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090609100243/http://www.me.berkeley.edu/cal/HCCI/ Research at University of California, Berkeley, USA] * [http://como.cheng.cam.ac.uk/index.php?Page=Research&Section=Engines&Subsection=HCCI Research at the University of Cambridge, UK] * [http://www.sfb686.rwth-aachen.de Research at RWTH Aachen University, Germany] * [http://www.combustion.tue.nl Research at Eindhoven University of Technology, The Netherlands] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20111008012026/http://www.t3.lanl.gov/ Research at Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, New Mexico, USA] ==Further reading== *[http://crf.sandia.gov/index.php/combustion-research-facility/engine-combustion/automotive/automotive-hcci-engine-research/#.TxBMfoEXFFs Automotive HCCI Engine] by Sandia Combustion Research Facility, January 2012. {{Automobile configuration}} {{Thermodynamic cycles}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Homogeneous Charge Compression Ignition}} [[Category:Thermodynamic cycles]] [[Category:Energy conversion]] [[Category:Engines]]

The '''Interaction Design Foundation''' is a non-profit educational organization<ref name='theaboutpage'>{{cite web |title=IDF about page |url= http://www.interaction-design.org/about/ |date = 2013-11-11}}</ref> which produces [[open content]] and [[Open access|Open Access]] educational materials<ref name='encyclopedia'>{{cite web |title=The Encyclopedia of Human Computer Interaction|url= http://www.interaction-design.org/encyclopedia/ |date = 2013-11-11}}</ref><ref name='forbesArticles'>{{cite web |title=Forbes.com:Meet The Danish NGO That's Taking Open-Source Education Global |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jmaureenhenderson/2013/09/24/meet-the-danish-ngo-thats-taking-open-source-education-global/ |date = 2013-09-24|publisher=Forbes.com}}</ref> online with the stated goal of "democratizing education by making world-class educational materials free for anyone, anywhere."<ref name='core77'>{{cite web |title=Core77.com: An Open Courseware Series of Textbooks for Design |url= http://core77.com/blog/articles/an_open_courseware_series_of_textbooks_for_design_25519.asp |date = 2013-09-11|publisher=Core77}}</ref><ref name=missionstatement>{{cite web|title=IDF Mission Statement|url=http://www.interaction-design.org/about/#mission_statement|publisher=The Interaction Design Foundation}}</ref>
Materials are learning materials at graduate level targeted at both industry and academia in the fields of [[interaction design]], [[computer science]], [[user experience]], [[information architecture]], and design. The centerpiece of the Interaction-Design.org is the [[peer review]]ed ''Encyclopedia of Human-Computer Interaction'', which currently number 40+ textbooks written by 100+ leading designers and professors as well as commentaries and HD video interviews shot around the world.<ref name=encyclopedia /><ref name=JohnnyHolland>{{cite web|title=Philosophy of Interaction|url=http://johnnyholland.org/2011/12/philosophy-of-interaction/|publisher=Johnny Holland Magazine|accessdate=28 January 2013}}</ref><ref name=murmurations>{{cite web|title=‘Affective Computing’ – Affective Interaction|url=http://murmurations.kuenen.org/2012/01/20/affective-computing-affective-interaction/|accessdate=28 January 2013}}</ref><ref name=InnovativeInteractivity>{{cite web|title=Interaction-design launches free multimedia encyclopedia|url=http://innovativeinteractivity.com/2011/02/06/interaction-design-encyclopedia/|publisher=Innovative Interactivity|accessdate=28 January 2013}}</ref><ref name=UsabilityNews>{{cite web|title=Review: An Interaction Design Encyclopedia opens its Pages|url=http://usabilitynews.bcs.org/content/conWebDoc/46561|publisher=Usability News|accessdate=28 January 2013}}</ref><ref name=GeoffreyDorne>{{cite web|title=L’Encyclopédie ultime du design d’Interaction !|url=http://graphism.fr/lencyclopdie-ultime-du-design-dinteraction|publisher=Graphisme & Interactivite par Geoffrey Dorne|accessdate=28 January 2013}}</ref><ref name=InteractiveMultimediaTechnology>{{cite web|title="Where am I in this information space?" Bifocal Display Concept Video, 1982, via the Interaction Design.org Encyclopedia|url=http://interactivemultimediatechnology.blogspot.com/2011/02/where-am-i-in-this-information-space.html|publisher=Interactive Multimedia Technology|accessdate=28 January 2013}}</ref> The website features professional and academic textbooks, video lectures, a conference calendar, and a comprehensive bibliography of the most authoritative publications within the design of interactive technology.
In June 2013, the Interaction Design Foundation launched a 4 year 35,000 mile bike tour, named "Share the Knowledge Tour",<ref name=officialTourSite>{{cite web|title=Share The Knowledge Tour|url=http://tour.interaction-design.org|publisher=Share the Knowledge Tour official website|accessdate=28 November 2013}}</ref> to raise awareness of the rising cost of education - with weekly events on university campuses.<ref name=NCAT>{{cite web|title=Share The Knowledge Tour Visits North Carolina State University|url=http://www.ncat.edu/news/2013/05/cyclist-presentation.html|publisher=North Carolina State University|accessdate=28 November 2013}}</ref><ref name=lanthorn>{{cite web|title=Share the Knowledge Tour to visit GVSU|url=http://www.lanthorn.com/article/2013/07/share-the-knowledge-tour-to-visit-gvsu|publisher=Grand Valley State University|accessdate=29 November 2013}}</ref>
Financial sponsors include the German software company [[SAP AG|SAP]]. Authors include Harvard professor [[Clayton M. Christensen|Clayton Christensen]]<ref name=DisruptiveInnovation>{{cite web|last=Christensen|first=Clayton|title=Disruptive Innovation|url=http://www.interaction-design.org/encyclopedia/disruptive_innovation.html|work=In: Soegaard, Mads and Dam, Rikke Friis (eds.). "The Encyclopedia of Human-Computer Interaction, 2nd Ed|publisher=Aarhus, Denmark: The Interaction Design Foundation|accessdate=28 January 2013}}</ref><ref name=NormanCommentary>{{cite web|last=Norman|first=Donald|title=Disruptive Innovation: Commentary on Christensen|url=http://www.jnd.org/dn.mss/disruptive_innovatio.html}}</ref> and New York Times bestselling author, Robert Spence<ref name=BifocalDisplay>{{cite web|last=Robert Spence|first=Mark Apperley|title=Bifocal Display|url=http://interaction-design.org/encyclopedia/bifocal_display.html|work=In: Soegaard, Mads and Dam, Rikke Friis (eds.). "The Encyclopedia of Human-Computer Interaction, 2nd Ed|publisher=Aarhus, Denmark: The Interaction Design Foundation|accessdate=28 January 2013}}</ref> who invented the "magnifying glass" visualization that is familiar to anyone with an iPhone or iMac, and [[Stuart Card|Stu Card]]<ref name=BifocalDisplay /> who performed the research that led to the computer mouse's commercial introduction by Xerox.
The Executive Board currently include [[Donald Norman|Don Norman]], [[Ken Friedman]], [[Bill Buxton]], Irene Au, Michael Arent, Daniel Rosenberg, Jonas Lowgren and Olof Schybergson.
